articles.headline: Robert Novak Has Brain Tumor
articles.snippet: The columnist Robert Novak has a brain tumor and will stop writing and making television appearances, at least temporarily.
articles.abstract: The columnist Robert Novak has a brain tumor and will stop writing and making television appearances, at least temporarily.
articles.lead_paragraph: The columnist Robert Novak has a brain tumor and will stop writing and making television appearances, at least temporarily.

articles.headline: White House Predicts $482 Billion Deficit
articles.snippet: The White House predicted that President Bush would leave a record $482 billion deficit to his successor, a turnabout in the nation’s fiscal condition from 2001.
articles.abstract: The White House predicted that President Bush would leave a record $482 billion deficit to his successor, a turnabout in the nation’s fiscal condition from 2001.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The White House predicted Monday that President Bush would leave a record $482 billion deficit to his successor, a sobering turnabout in the nation’s fiscal condition from 2001, when Mr. Bush took office after three consecutive years of budget surpluses.
articles.byline: By Robert Pear and David M. Herszenhorn

articles.headline: Bombers and Ethnic Clashes Kill 61 in Iraq
articles.snippet: Suicide bombers struck Kurdish protesters in Kirkuk and Shiite pilgrims in Baghdad in one of the deadliest series of attacks in Iraq this year.
articles.abstract: Suicide bombers struck Kurdish protesters in Kirkuk and Shiite pilgrims in Baghdad in one of the deadliest series of attacks in Iraq this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  Three women wrapped in explosives killed dozens in Iraq on Monday, shaking the country as chaos and ethnic violence erupted in the volatile northern city of Kirkuk, where tensions had already run high between majority Kurds and ethnic Turkmens.
articles.byline: By Richard A. Oppel Jr. and Sabrina Tavernise

articles.headline: Write-Down Is Planned at Merrill
articles.snippet: Merrill Lynch said it expected to take a $5.7 billion write-down because of losses on its mortgage assets.
articles.abstract: Merrill Lynch said it expected to take a $5.7 billion write-down because of losses on its mortgage assets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Only 10 days after stunning Wall Street with a huge quarterly loss, Merrill Lynch unexpectedly disclosed another multibillion-dollar write-down on Monday and sought to bolster its finances once again by selling new stock to the public and to an investment company controlled by Singapore.

articles.headline: In Detainee Trial, System Is Tested
articles.snippet: At the first trial for a Guantánamo detainee, two trials are unfolding at once: one for Salim Hamdan and one for the military commission system.
articles.abstract: At the first trial for a Guantánamo detainee, two trials are unfolding at once: one for Salim Hamdan and one for the military commission system.
articles.lead_paragraph: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba  On the surface, the proceedings unfolding inside a makeshift courthouse on a hill here resemble an American trial. A judge wearing a black robe presides. There is a public gallery and a witness stand. Prosecutors present witnesses, and defense lawyers cross-examine them. Objections are made and ruled upon.

articles.headline: A New Way to Generate Mortgages
articles.snippet: Regulators, bankers and traders, led by Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., all pledged to do their best to get a “covered bond market” going in the U.S.
articles.abstract: Regulators, bankers and traders, led by Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., all pledged to do their best to get a “covered bond market” going in the U.S.
articles.lead_paragraph: The financial establishment came together Monday in search of a new way for banks to come up with cash for home mortgages. Regulators, bankers and traders, led by Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., all pledged to do their best to get a “covered bond market” going in the United States.

articles.headline: Lax Lending Standards Led to IndyMac’s Downfall
articles.snippet: The collapse of IndyMac, one of the nation’s largest mortgage lenders, was the most vivid example to date of the dangers confronting banks and their investors.
articles.abstract: The collapse of IndyMac, one of the nation’s largest mortgage lenders, was the most vivid example to date of the dangers confronting banks and their investors.
articles.lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif.  After his mortgage company nearly crashed a decade ago, Michael W. Perry set a new course. He bought a bank so the company, soon rechristened IndyMac Bank, would never run short of money again.

articles.headline: A Call for a Warning System on Artificial Joints
articles.snippet: If American patients who ended up with agonizing hip replacements lived in certain other industrialized countries, many might have been spared the risk.
articles.abstract: If American patients who ended up with agonizing hip replacements lived in certain other industrialized countries, many might have been spared the risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dr. Lawrence Dorr, a nationally known orthopedic surgeon in Los Angeles, realized last year that something was very wrong with some of his patients.

articles.headline: Gas Rush Is On, and Louisianians Cash In
articles.snippet: A no-holds-barred, all-American gold rush for natural gas is under way in a forgotten corner of the South.
articles.abstract: A no-holds-barred, all-American gold rush for natural gas is under way in a forgotten corner of the South.
articles.lead_paragraph: MANSFIELD, La.  They had to repeat the amazing number, $28.7 million, over and over, to make sure it was real and would not go away. Even then, the members of the De Soto Parish Police Jury  the county commission  could hardly believe it.

articles.headline: Find an Undervalued Asset. Fix It Up. Flip It. (Now It’s Web Sites, Not Houses)
articles.snippet: A wave of entrepreneurs are using free software to buy niche Web sites and fix them up with the hope of reselling them.
articles.abstract: A wave of entrepreneurs are using free software to buy niche Web sites and fix them up with the hope of reselling them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Dave Hermansen did not own a bird or a cage when he bought bird-cage.com, an online store, for $1,800 three years ago. He simply saw a Web site that was “very, very poorly done,” and begged the owners to sell it to him. He then redesigned the site, added advertising and drove up traffic. Last December, he sold it for $173,000.
